This manual describes version &toolversion; of &tool;.
Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &tool; or this manual, follow the directions in the GNOME Feedback Page.
The &tool; allows you to specify which services will be started during the system boot process, as well as starting or stopping them instantly.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &tool; allows you to specify which services will be started during the system boot process, as well as starting or stopping them instantly.

sect1.title: Getting started
sect1.para: You can start &tool; in the following ways:
When you start &tool;, you will be prompted for the administrator password, this is necessary because the changes done with this tool will affect the whole system.
After entering the administrator password, the following window is displayed.
The &tool; main window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: This drop-down menu allows you to tune your services' behavior by expressly telling them under which circumstances do they must start (i.e: enabled in graphical mode, while disabled in text mode). This menu may not exist if your system has not the concept of runlevels.
This is a list of all the services installed in the system, telling whether they're active in the runlevel selected in the runlevels menu.
By default the services list has alphabetical order, turn on this checkbox to order the services by priority. This item may not exist if your system has not the concept of priority.
This button displays more information about the selected service.

sect2.title: To enable or disable a service at boot time
sect2.para: Turn up or down the checkbox beside the service in the services list.

sect2.title: To enable or disable a service inmediately
sect2.para: Select a service, click on the Service properties button and click on the Start or Stop buttons.

sect2.title: To change a service startup sequence
sect2.para: Select a service, click on the Service properties button and change the priority. If you have selected the Order list by startup sequence checkbox, you will see the selected service moving through the list. If your system does not have the concept of priorities, the spinbutton will not exist
